data: Transpose a matrix of shape (2,3,3). Multiply the result with a matrix of shape (3,2,2). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (3,3,2).

Transposing a (2,3,3) matrix results in a shape of (3,3,2). Multiplying it with a (3,2,2) matrix results in a shape of (3,3,2). Computing the Kronecker product with a (3,3,2) matrix results in a shape of (9,9,4).
Subtract a matrix of shape (2,2,3) from a matrix of shape (2,2,3). Sum the result over the second axis.
When subtracting two matrices of shape (2,2,3), the resulting matrix will also have shape (2,2,3). Summing over the second axis will collapse the second axis, resulting in a final shape of (2,3).
Compute the hadamard product of a matrix of shape (3,2) with a matrix of shape (3,2). Transpose the result.

The Hadamard product of two matrices of the same shape results in a matrix of the same shape. Therefore, the resulting matrix from the Hadamard product will also be of shape (3,2). Transposing a matrix does not change its shape.
Subtract a matrix of shape (2,3,2) from a matrix of shape (2,3,2). Multiply the result with a matrix of shape (2,2,3).

When subtracting two matrices of the same shape (2,3,2), the resulting matrix will also have the same shape (2,3,2). Then, when multiplying this result with a matrix of shape (2,2,3), the inner dimensions must match, resulting in a final shape of (2,3,3).
Multiply a matrix of shape (3,3,3,2) with a matrix of shape (3,3,2,4). Multiply the result with a matrix of shape (3,3,4,3). Transpose the result.

The first multiplication will result in a matrix of shape (3,3,3,4). The second multiplication will result in a matrix of shape (3,3,3,3). Transposing the final matrix will result in a shape of (3,3,3,3).

Take a matrix of shape (2,3,2) and sum over the first axis. Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (3,2). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (4,4). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (3,2).

The initial matrix shape is (2,3,2). Summing over the first axis results in a shape of (3,2). The kronecker product with a (3,2) matrix results in a shape of (9,4). The kronecker product with a (4,4) matrix results in a shape of (36,16). Finally, the kronecker product with a (3,2) matrix results in a shape of (108,32).

Compute the kronecker product of a matrix of shape (2,3,3,2) with a matrix of shape (4,3,3,2). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (2,4,4,2). Subtract the result from a matrix of shape (16,36,36,8). Add the result to a matrix of shape (16,36,36,8).

The kronecker product of two matrices of shapes (a1, b1, c1, d1) and (a2, b2, c2, d2) results in a matrix of shape (a1*a2, b1*b2, c1*c2, d1*d2). Therefore, the first kronecker product results in a matrix of shape (8, 9, 6, 4). The second kronecker product results in a matrix of shape (16, 36, 24, 8). Subtracting this from a (16, 36, 36, 8) matrix and then adding it back will result in a matrix of shape (16, 36, 36, 8).
Transpose a matrix of shape (3,2,3). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (4,2,2). Multiply the result with a matrix of shape (12,6,3).

Transposing a (3,2,3) matrix results in a shape of (3,3,2). The Kronecker product with a (4,2,2) matrix will result in a shape of (3*4,3*2,2*2) = (12,6,4). Multiplying this with a (12,6,3) matrix will result in a final shape of (12,6,3).
Compute the hadamard product of a matrix of shape (3,2) with a matrix of shape (3,2).

The Hadamard product of two matrices is the element-wise product of the corresponding elements. Since both matrices have the same shape (3,2), the resulting matrix will also have the same shape. Each element in the resulting matrix will be the product of the corresponding elements in the original matrices.

Multiply a matrix of shape (2,2,2,3) with a matrix of shape (2,2,3,3). Add the result to a matrix of shape (2,2,2,3). Compute the hadamard product of the result with a matrix of shape (2,2,2,3). Compute the hadamard product of the result with a matrix of shape (2,2,2,3). Add the result to a matrix of shape (2,2,2,3). Multiply the result with a matrix of shape (2,2,3,2).

The first multiplication will result in a matrix of shape (2,2,2,3) since the inner dimensions match. Adding a matrix of shape (2,2,2,3) will preserve the shape. The Hadamard product with another matrix of shape (2,2,2,3) will also result in the same shape. Finally, multiplying with a matrix of shape (2,2,3,2) will result in a shape of (2,2,2,2).

Add a matrix of shape (3,2) to a matrix of shape (3,2). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (2,4). Subtract the result from a matrix of shape (6,8). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (3,2).

The addition of two matrices of shape (3,2) results in a matrix of shape (3,2). The kronecker product with a matrix of shape (2,4) results in a matrix of shape (3*2, 2*4) = (6,8). Subtracting this from a matrix of shape (6,8) results in a matrix of shape (6,8). The kronecker product with a matrix of shape (3,2) results in a final shape of (6*3, 8*2) = (18,16).
Add a matrix of shape (3,2,3) to a matrix of shape (3,2,3). Multiply the result with a matrix of shape (3,3,2).

When adding two matrices of shape (3,2,3), the resulting shape will remain the same, i.e., (3,2,3). Then, when multiplying this result with a matrix of shape (3,3,2), the inner dimensions must match, resulting in a final shape of (3,2,2).
Take a matrix of shape (3,3,2) and sum over the third axis.

Summing over the third axis of a matrix of shape (3,3,2) means collapsing the third axis by adding the values at each corresponding position. This operation will result in a new matrix with shape (3,3).

Compute the hadamard product of a matrix of shape (2,3) with a matrix of shape (2,3). Add the result to a matrix of shape (2,3). Multiply the result with a matrix of shape (3,4). Add the result to a matrix of shape (2,4).

The Hadamard product of two matrices of shape (2,3) results in a matrix of the same shape (2,3). Adding this to another matrix of shape (2,3) gives a matrix of shape (2,3). Multiplying this with a matrix of shape (3,4) results in a matrix of shape (2,4). Adding this to a matrix of shape (2,4) gives a final shape of (2,4).

Compute the hadamard product of a matrix of shape (3,3,3,3) with a matrix of shape (3,3,3,3). Sum the result over the fourth axis. Multiply the result with a matrix of shape (3,3,2). Transpose the result. Subtract the result from a matrix of shape (2,3,3).

The Hadamard product of two matrices of shape (3,3,3,3) results in a matrix of the same shape. Summing over the fourth axis gives a matrix of shape (3,3,3). Multiplying with a matrix of shape (3,3,2) results in a matrix of shape (3,3,2). Transposing it gives a shape of (2,3,3). Subtracting from a matrix of shape (2,3,3) results in a shape of (2,3,3).
Compute the kronecker product of a matrix of shape (2,2,3,2) with a matrix of shape (3,4,2,4).

The kronecker product of two matrices A of shape (a1, a2, a3, a4) and B of shape (b1, b2, b3, b4) results in a matrix of shape (a1*b1, a2*b2, a3*b3, a4*b4). Therefore, the final shape after performing the kronecker product is (6, 8, 6, 8).
Compute the hadamard product of a matrix of shape (3,3,3,3) with a matrix of shape (3,3,3,3). Transpose the result. Subtract the result from a matrix of shape (3,3,3,3). Transpose the result.

The Hadamard product of two matrices of the same shape results in a matrix of the same shape. Transposing a matrix does not change its shape. Subtracting two matrices of the same shape results in a matrix of the same shape. Therefore, the final shape will be (3,3,3,3).

Transpose a matrix of shape (2,3). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (4,4). Multiply the result with a matrix of shape (8,4). Subtract the result from a matrix of shape (12,4). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (3,2).

Transposing a (2,3) matrix results in a (3,2) matrix. The Kronecker product of a (3,2) matrix with a (4,4) matrix results in a (12,8) matrix. Multiplying a (12,8) matrix with a (8,4) matrix results in a (12,4) matrix. Subtracting a (12,4) matrix from a (12,4) matrix results in a (12,4) matrix. The Kronecker product of a (12,4) matrix with a (3,2) matrix results in a (36,8) matrix.
Add a matrix of shape (2,2) to a matrix of shape (2,2). Subtract the result from a matrix of shape (2,2). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (4,2).
Finalresult:(8,4)

Adding two matrices of shape (2,2) results in a matrix of shape (2,2). Subtracting this from another matrix of shape (2,2) gives a matrix of shape (2,2). The Kronecker product of a (2,2) matrix with a (4,2) matrix results in a final matrix shape of (8,4).

Multiply a matrix of shape (3,2,3) with a matrix of shape (3,3,2). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (4,3,2). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (2,3,2). Compute the hadamard product of the result with a matrix of shape (24,18,8).

The first matrix multiplication will result in a shape of (3,2,2). The kronecker product with a (4,3,2) matrix will result in a shape of (12,6,4). The kronecker product with a (2,3,2) matrix will result in a shape of (24,18,8). The Hadamard product will maintain the shape.

Take a matrix of shape (3,3,3) and sum over the third axis. Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (3,3). Subtract the result from a matrix of shape (9,9). Subtract the result from a matrix of shape (9,9). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (3,2).

The sum over the third axis of a (3,3,3) matrix results in a (3,3) matrix. The Kronecker product with a (3,3) matrix gives a (9,9) matrix. Subtracting this from a (9,9) matrix results in a (9,9) matrix. The Kronecker product with a (3,2) matrix gives a final shape of (27,18).

Transpose a matrix of shape (3,2,2). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (2,3,4). Subtract the result from a matrix of shape (4,6,12). Add the result to a matrix of shape (4,6,12).

Transposing a matrix of shape (3,2,2) results in a shape of (2,2,3). The Kronecker product with a matrix of shape (2,3,4) results in a shape of (2,2,3,2,3,4). Subtracting from a matrix of shape (4,6,12) and adding to a matrix of shape (4,6,12) keeps the shape unchanged.

Transpose a matrix of shape (3,3). Multiply the result with a matrix of shape (3,1). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (3,3). Transpose the result. Multiply the result with a matrix of shape (9,2).

The kronecker product of two matrices of shapes (a,b,c,d) and (e,f,g,h) results in a matrix of shape (a*e, b*f, c*g, d*h). In this case, the kronecker product of a (2,3,3,3) matrix with a (2,2,2,2) matrix will result in a matrix of shape (4,6,6,6).
Compute the kronecker product of a matrix of shape (2,3) with a matrix of shape (3,2).

The kronecker product of two matrices A (m x n) and B (p x q) results in a matrix of shape (mp, nq). In this case, the kronecker product of a (2,3) matrix with a (3,2) matrix will result in a matrix of shape (2*3, 3*2) = (6, 6).
Transpose a matrix of shape (2,2,2).

Compute the kronecker product of a matrix of shape (3,2,2) with a matrix of shape (3,3,4). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (3,4,2).

Subtract a matrix of shape (3,2,3) from a matrix of shape (3,2,3). Compute the hadamard product of the result with a matrix of shape (3,2,3). Transpose the result. Add the result to a matrix of shape (3,2,3). Multiply the result with a matrix of shape (3,3,2).

The subtraction of two matrices of shape (3,2,3) results in a matrix of shape (3,2,3). The Hadamard product with another matrix of shape (3,2,3) keeps the shape unchanged. Transposing the matrix still gives a shape of (3,2,3). Adding it to a matrix of shape (3,2,3) results in the same shape. Finally, multiplying with a matrix of shape (3,3,2) gives a shape of (3,2,2).
Subtract a matrix of shape (3,3) from a matrix of shape (3,3).
Subtracting two matrices of the same shape results in a matrix of the same shape. In this case, subtracting a (3,3) matrix from another (3,3) matrix will yield a matrix of shape (3,3).
Take a matrix of shape (2,2,2) and sum over the second axis.

When summing over the second axis of a matrix with shape (2,2,2), the elements along the second axis will be summed up, resulting in a new matrix with shape (2,2). The first and third axes remain unchanged.

Compute the kronecker product of a matrix of shape (3,3) with a matrix of shape (3,2). Add the result to a matrix of shape (9,6). Compute the hadamard product of the result with a matrix of shape (9,6). Multiply the result with a matrix of shape (6,1). Multiply the result with a matrix of shape (1,3).

The Kronecker product of a (3,3) matrix with a (3,2) matrix results in a (9,6) matrix. Adding this to a (9,6) matrix gives another (9,6) matrix. The Hadamard product with a (9,6) matrix keeps the shape as (9,6). Multiplying by a (6,1) matrix results in a (9,1) matrix. Finally, multiplying by a (1,3) matrix gives a final shape of (9,3).
Transpose a matrix of shape (2,2,2,3). Add the result to a matrix of shape (3,2,2,2).
Transposing a matrix of shape (2,2,2,3) results in a shape of (3,2,2,2). Adding this transposed matrix to a matrix of shape (3,2,2,2) will result in the same shape.

Add a matrix of shape (2,2,3) to a matrix of shape (2,2,3). Subtract the result from a matrix of shape (2,2,3). Compute the hadamard product of the result with a matrix of shape (2,2,3). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (2,2,3).

The initial addition and subtraction operations will maintain the shape of (2,2,3). The Hadamard product with another (2,2,3) matrix will still result in a shape of (2,2,3) as it operates element-wise. Finally, the Kronecker product will expand the shape to (4,4,9).

Subtract a matrix of shape (2,3,3,2) from a matrix of shape (2,3,3,2). Compute the hadamard product of the result with a matrix of shape (2,3,3,2). Sum the result over the third axis. Subtract the result from a matrix of shape (2,3,2). Compute the kronecker product of the result with a matrix of shape (4,3,3). Transpose the result.

The subtraction of two matrices of shape (2,3,3,2) results in a matrix of shape (2,3,3,2). The Hadamard product with a matrix of shape (2,3,3,2) keeps the shape unchanged. Summing over the third axis results in a shape of (2,3,2). Subtracting from a matrix of shape (2,3,2) keeps the shape unchanged. The Kronecker product with a matrix of shape (4,3,3) results in a shape of (2,3,2,4,3,3). Transposing the result gives a final shape of (3,2,4,3,3).
Take a matrix of shape (2,3,2) and sum over the first axis. Add the result to a matrix of shape (3,2). Transpose the result. Multiply the result with a matrix of shape (3,4).

The initial matrix has shape (2,3,2). Summing over the first axis results in a matrix of shape (3,2). Adding this to a matrix of shape (3,2) gives a matrix of shape (3,2). Transposing it results in a matrix of shape (2,3). Multiplying this with a matrix of shape (3,4) gives a final shape of (2,4).
